Project Description  The Second Decentralized Health Services Project (DHS2) will support 
comprehensive reform and capacity-building efforts of the Ministry of 
Health (MOH) and the National Family Coordinating Board (BKKBN) in 
the context of decentralization. Focusing on the needs of the poor, the 
DHS2 will increase the quality and effectiveness of health and family 
planning  services  in  the  project  area  by  improving  clinical  and 
managerial skills of health personnel, upgrading health facilities and 
equipment, and involving civil society in planning and monitoring of 
service provision. 
   
Rationale  Decentralization  offers  new  opportunities  to  strengthen  health  and 
family planning services in the regions through locally adapted reforms 
giving  health  services  providers  more  appropriate  incentives,  skills, 
supervision,  material  support,  and  discretionary  authority  needed  to 
offer  high  quality  services,  and  providing  clients  with  information, 
financial means, and bargaining power required to elicit appropriate 
responses.  A  mix  of  human,  physical,  and  financial  resources  are 
needed  to  help  the  regions  and  the  central  Government  plan, 
implement, manage, monitor, and evaluate a range of programs and 
activities.  Low  quality  of  public  health  services  in  Indonesia  affects 
mainly the poor and vulnerable groups and is linked to a range of 
shortcomings in the health sector, which indicate chronic underfunding. 
The  DHS2  will  address  these  deficits  while  focusing  on  the  health 
needs of the poor. A better health status will give the poor and the 
community  at  large  greater  opportunity  to  fully  participate  in  the 
economic development of their specific region and the country.  
   
Objectives  The DHS2 will help improve the health status of people in 8 provinces 
of Indonesia, particularly concentrating on improving health services 
geared to women, children, and infants.  The DHS2 will increase the 
clinical and managerial capacity of health personnel at all levels of 
government, strengthen regulatory and quality assurance functions, and 
result in improved local health and family planning services.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to the Republic of Indonesia for the Second Decentralized Health Services Project (DHS2).1 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  From 1970 to 2001, life expectancy at birth increased from 46 to 64 years of age for 
males and to 68 years of age for females, reflecting the decline in the infant and under-5 
mortality rates. Infant mortality declined from 145 to 33 infant deaths and under-5 mortality 
declined from 172 to 45 per thousand live births. Easier access to health services combined 
with economic growth and better education contributed to improving the health status. However, 
Indonesia’s health status indicators remain low2 and achievements have been uneven across 
provinces,  between  urban  and  rural  areas,  and  between  rich  and  poor  segments  of  the 
population. With 25% of all under-5-year-old children underweight and 50% of pregnant women 
suffering from iron deficiency anemia, malnutrition remains a public health issue. Maternal 
mortality, estimated at 380 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, is unacceptably high. While 
cardiovascular and chronic diseases have become the main causes of mortality, infectious and 
parasitic diseases, which particularly affect the poor, dominate morbidity. Tuberculosis, malaria, 
respiratory infections, and diarrhea remain major public health issues. This combination of 
chronic, life-style, and infectious diseases creates a double burden of diseases for the health 
system of the country. A detailed description of the health sector and its performance in the 
project area is in Appendix 2. 
 
3.  Over the last 3 decades, Indonesia has given priority to improving physical access to 
primary health care (PHC) services. The average distance to a health facility in 2002 was 5 
kilometers in rural areas and 1.5 kilometers in urban areas, but chronic underfunding and 
inefficient targeting has prevented better results. Total national expenditures for health have 
been low by international standards. In 1995, only 1.6% of gross domestic product was spent on 
health.  The  proportion  increased  to  2.7%  in  2000,  but  the  Government’s  share  of  health 
expenditure, excluding external aid, fell from 46.0% in 1995 to 23.7%. The percentage of central 
Government expenditure allocated to the health sector is only 2%, compared with 5% in the 
Philippines and 8% in Thailand. Health expenditure per capita ($19) is below the average of 
low-income countries ($21), the Philippines ($33), and Thailand ($71). Chronic underfunding 
has affected maintenance of facilities; procurement of medical equipment, drugs, and other 
supplies; and the quality of training for health workers, before and after graduation. A low 30% 
utilization rate of public health services suggests low client satisfaction.  
 
4.  Consultations in the villages during project preparation confirmed that low quality and 
inadequate services that do not respond to needs felt by the local population were important 
reasons for low utilization of public health services. For the poor, even minimal user fees can be 
an obstacle to the use of health services. The World Bank found that the richest 20% of the

5.  The Government has developed a successful family planning program advocating birth 
spacing, small families, and family welfare.4 Spearheaded by the National Family Planning

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
6.  Since January 2001, regional governments are responsible for financing and delivery of 
health  services  in  the  context  of  regional  autonomy  and  decentralization.  With  second-tier 
regional governments now being the deciding authority regarding health policies and budget 
allocations for their regions, the national and provincial authorities cannot determine the health 
agenda of districts and cities anymore. This raises issues of coordination and regulation as well 
as  of  quality  assurance.  The  announcement  of  obligatory  functions  and  minimum  service 
standards has given the national Government an important tool to ensure quality and regulation 
in the sector. This will allow the Ministry of Health (MOH) to specifically address shortcomings of 
regional health services in relation to defined service standards. Project-related annual health 
sector  plans  of  regional  governments  as  practiced  by  the  ongoing  Decentralized  Health 
Services (DHS1) Project provide another opportunity to enforce quality and compliance with 
defined standards because plans have to be consistent with the central Government's norms 
and quality requirements. 
 
7.  Decentralization can increase accountability of health service providers and regional 
authorities and offer greater opportunity for the community to influence resource allocation and 
service quality. Since the allocation of resources is now decided by elected regional authorities 
and no longer by technocrats in the central Government, allocation criteria and priorities have 
become  part  of  the  political  debate.  Without  appropriate  capacity  building  and  advocacy, 
regional governments may not become aware of the benefits of investing in health and family 
planning, and health needs of poor and vulnerable groups may not become a political priority. 
Although quality PHC services, maternal and child health, and nutrition programs are universally 
recognized to be highly cost-effective programs that benefit the poor, regional governments may 
prefer  to  invest  in  high  profile  hospitals  that  would  undermine  sector  cost-effectiveness. 
Decentralization requires a new approach and a new role from MOH different from the previous 
focus on top-down planning and budgeting.  
 
8.  Equally, new skills and knowledge are required at the regional levels. In a decentralized 
environment, regional health staff are in charge of needs identification, planning, budgeting, 
monitoring,  and  evaluation.  Essential  drugs  must  be  purchased  and  health  staff  must  be 
properly  qualified  to  prescribe  them  in  an  appropriate  manner.  Even  with  qualified  health 
personnel, poor health facilities and insufficient medical equipment prevent the provision of 
quality services. Also, financing of the health services in terms of cost sharing between different

9.  The quantity and qualification of primary health workers is a major issue. Indonesia has 
on average one doctor per 6,000–7,000 people, but the situation is worse in rural areas where 
remote localities remain underserved with less than one doctor per health center. Young doctors 
and midwives are required to provide PHC services under a 3-year compulsory contract. The 
doctors work in district hospitals and health centers and midwives are posted in health centers 
and in small village-based health facilities. Incentives, benefits, and opportunities vary and 
depend largely on the individual regional government. Specialized doctors tend to move toward 
bigger urban centers, which offer better professional opportunities and monetary incentives. 
This creates a major problem for the recruitment and retention of qualified health personnel in 
districts, cities, and provinces that cannot provide such incentives.  
 
10.  Village midwives are most often the first contact of the rural population when it comes to 
health services and provide services that are much appreciated by the poor. Their training, 
however, does not equip them to deliver quality PHC services. There is a need to offer regular 
training, supervision, and necessary equipment and essential drugs.5 MOH is implementing a 
new training policy to address this issue, developing hospital-based training in provinces and in 
selected districts, expecting to attract local professionals that will stay in the region.  
 
11.  Starting  on  1  January  2004,  BKKBN  will  have  to  decentralize  its  successful  family 
planning services, and regional governments will become responsible for ensuring access to the 
family planning and reproductive health programs. BKKBN’s vision is to help Indonesian families 
become prosperous, healthy, and independent, with two children only, and to provide access to 
family planning services for the poor. A particular policy of BKKBN is to ensure continuous 
availability of free or subsidized contraceptives for the poor. However, this policy may be difficult 
to maintain because major donors—in particular the United States Agency for International 
Development—have announced their withdrawal from the population and family planning sector.  
 
12.  MOH and BKKBN are obliged by decentralization laws to adjust to new roles that include 
regulatory and standardization functions; provision of guidance and capacity building; reform of 
the health sector, including health care financing; mobilization of resources; and monitoring and 
evaluation of service quality. MOH has developed a list of essential health services that must be 
provided by districts and municipalities.6  The delivery of such services is in the hands of 
regional governments, and MOH's and BKKBN's role is to advocate a comprehensive and 
integrated approach to health problems instead of implementing activities through line agencies.  
 
13.  Ensuring universal access to PHC services, better targeting of the poor and vulnerable 
groups, and mobilization of new resources for health care financing are MOH’s and BKKBN’s 
priority strategies, which have been linked to the achievement of the health-related Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs). The Government is committed to achieving the MDGs. But without 
addressing specific health needs of the poor, the MDG targets will be difficult to achieve. MOH 
has defined four priority strategies in the context of its Healthy Indonesia 2010 Strategy that 
describes MOH’s new vision, mission, and direction: health-conscious national development,

15.  External  assistance  to  Indonesia’s  health  sector  increased  from  about  $573  million 
between 1994 and 1997 to approximately $2.24 billion from 1998 to 2002. The main sources of 
assistance were ADB, World Bank, Japan Bank for International Cooperation, United States 
Agency for International Development, Australian Agency for International Development, the 
Netherlands, and the specialized United Nations (UN) agencies: UN Development Programme 
(UNDP), UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF), UN Population Fund (UNFPA), and World Health 
Organization (WHO). External assistance mainly supported health services quality, nutrition, 
community health, women’s health, and family planning. Details are provided in Appendix 3. 
 
C.  Lessons Learned 
16.  As part of a series of externally-financed projects supporting decentralization of the 
health  sector,  the  Project  is  a  geographical  extension  of  ADB’s  DHS1,9  and  incorporates 
lessons learned from the DHS1 and other ongoing projects, in particular the World Bank-
financed provincial health projects I and II and its Health Workforce and Service Project.  The 
lack  of  professional  and  management  skills  at  the  regional  level  emerged  as  the  biggest 
bottleneck in these projects. A technically strong central project implementation unit (PIU) that 
supports local implementation units proved to be essential for achieving project objectives. In 
addition, implementation arrangements need to clearly define the responsibilities of each level 
of governance, avoiding organizational ambiguities that can undermine system performance. In 
the Family Health and Nutrition Project,10 a technical adviser attached to the PIU played a 
decisive  role  ensuring  that  project  activities  remained  aligned  with  project  objectives.  This 
technical adviser proved instrumental in coordinating policies and guidelines from various MOH 
directorates.   
 
17.  Detailed  implementation  schedules  for  the  first  year  of  project  implementation  are 
essential  to  avoid  initial  delays  of  activities.  New  communication  technologies  in  terms  of 
electronic mail and Internet can help to overcome communication problems in a country as vast 
as Indonesia, though the required physical infrastructure may not be sufficiently developed in all 
regions. The severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) epidemic demonstrated that technical

18.  In 1998, spurred by the Asian economic crisis, the Government started implementing its 
Social Safety Net Program to protect access to social services for the poor.11 It was initiated as 
an  externally-supported  emergency  program  and  is  financed  in  the  meantime  by  special

MOH focused its efforts on PHC services, including emergency hospitalizations. The program, 
supported by ADB with two sector development programs, offered free access to essential 
health services for the poor at health centers and district hospitals using block grant subsidies to 
these  facilities;  a  health-center-based  feeding  program  for  infants,  children,  and  pregnant 
women; and increased outreach activities of the village midwives. As a result, visits to health 
centers increased and more deliveries were attended by trained health personnel. The Social 
Safety Net Program brought a significant infusion of cash resources for the health sector. 
Focusing on a limited number of activities that targeted the poor and vulnerable groups, this 
Program  has  protected  universal  access  to,  and  increased  utilization  of  essential  health 
services. 
 
19.  Health sector reforms are not always well understood by regional governments and 
require  guidance,  advocacy,  and  continued  dialogue  initiated  by  the  national  Government. 
Developing better coordination of public and private service provision at the regional level has 
been advocated by DHS1.  It took 2 years of persuasion before regional governments were 
willing to consider developing such partnerships. Still, advocacy is considered to be more 
successful than prescription by project design.  In view of weak capacities, flexibility is needed 
during project implementation to allow project beneficiaries to modify plans and priorities based 
on  their  increasing  knowledge  and  skills.  Thus,  a  mix  of  human,  physical,  and  financial 
resources  is  needed,  including  more  effective  bottom-up  planning  and  implementation 
mechanisms that promote stakeholder participation. Above all, health services must become 
responsive to the needs of the poor segments of society to have an impact on the health status 
of the population at large. 
  
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objective 
20.  The DHS2 Project will help improve the health of the population in the project area, as 
measured by health-related indicators of the MDGs, through better PHC services focusing on 
the needs of women, infants, children, and the poor. The purpose of the DHS2 is to improve 
health services in 8 provinces and 90 districts and cities.  
 
21.  The DHS2 will cover districts and cities in the following provinces: Bangka Belitung; 
Central and South Kalimantan; East and West Nusa Tenggara; Gorontalo; South Sulawesi; and 
South Sumatra. Bangka Belitung and Gorontalo are two newly created provinces that need 
special support to develop their management capacity. South Sumatra and Central and South 
Kalimantan were part of previous ADB-supported health sector projects and their participation in 
the DHS2 will enable them to consolidate previous achievements. In East and West Nusa 
Tenggara, the DHS2 will help integrate inputs of various externally-financed interventions to 
develop a more comprehensive and efficient local health system.

22.  The DHS2 aims at achieving (i) improved capacity at the regional level to ensure the 
provision of quality health and family planning services; (ii) local health services with improved 
equitability,  quality,  and  financially  sustainability;  and  (iii)  improved  capacity  of  MOH  and 
BKKBN to support regional governments to deliver such services. Capacity-building activities at 
all levels of government will provide much needed managerial and clinical skills to deliver quality 
PHC services and address the needs of the poor.  At least 50% of the participants in DHS2-
funded training programs will be women.  Investments in PHC facilities, vehicles and equipment, 
and the provision of essential drugs will complement capacity-building inputs of the DHS2.  
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
23.  The  DHS2  consists  of  three  components.  The  first  component  will  strengthen  the 
human, physical, and organizational capacity of districts and cities through (i) managerial and 
clinical  training;  (ii)  upgrading  of  health  facilities  and  purchase  of  equipment,  vehicles  for 
outreach activities, and essential medical supplies; (iii) development of institutional mechanisms 
that facilitate community participation and promote accountability and transparency of service 
providers through regional health committees; and (iv) strengthening of regulatory and licensing 
functions that protect the poor. The managerial training will cover health service planning and 
budgeting, health care financing, and monitoring and evaluation, and will promote participatory 
approaches to identify local health and family planning needs and to identify and implement 
technically appropriate and locally acceptable health programs. Clinical training for doctors, 
nurses,  and  midwives  will  be  evidence-based  and  on-site  at  health  centers  and  referral 
hospitals, focusing on PHC, maternal and child health, and communicable disease control. 
Upgrading of facilities concentrates mainly on the rehabilitation of health posts for midwives, 
health centers, subhealth centers, and selected district hospitals, with a limited scope for the 
construction of new facilities. Technical assistance will support advocacy workshops and public 
private  partnership  meetings  to  empower  district  health  committees  that  will  become 
instrumental  in  exploiting  the  opportunities  of  decentralization  in  terms  of  increased 
transparency, focus on local needs and conditions, and inclusion of civil society in the planning 
and delivery of health services. The DHS2 will provide guidelines that refocus the licensing and 
accreditation of personnel and health facilities on better quality and access to health services for 
women, vulnerable groups, and the poor. 
 
24.  The second component will develop professional capacity, improve referral regional 
hospitals and training facilities, and advocate health sector reforms at provincial level through (i) 
clinical training for specialists, health care managers, and trainers; (ii) upgrading or purchasing 
of new equipment; (iii) transforming provincial hospitals into local teaching institutions; (iv) 
supporting information and advocacy campaigns for health and family planning; and (v) support 
for regulatory functions and quality assurance by provincial governments. Under the guidance 
and with technical support of MOH and BKKBN, managerial training will be provided covering 
quality  assurance  and  the  design  of  specific  health  care  reforms  such  as  social  health 
insurance, public-private partnerships, referral systems, and coordination of drug procurement 
among districts and provinces. They will disseminate policies and guidelines from the national 
Government and information about successful practices. In-country fellowships and comparative 
studies will be offered to selected candidates. DHS2 funds will also be used to rehabilitate and 
provide  equipment  and  vehicles.  Women  will  be  given  priority  to  participate  in  all  training 
activities. Activities of this component will support MOH's policy to develop a local pool of 
qualified health professionals by using provincial hospitals as teaching hospitals. Capacity of 
provinces to regulate the health sector, oversee performance of district services, and ensure the 
implementation  of  minimum  service  standards  and  the  reform  of  health  centers  will  be

7
strengthened. The DHS2 funds will also be used to rehabilitate and provide equipment and 
vehicles for outreach activities. 
 
25.  The third component will support MOH and BKKBN to change from a command and 
control  leadership  role  to  new  functions  and  responsibilities  that  consist  of  consultation, 
coordination, provision of technical assistance to regional governments, provision of essential 
drugs for the poor, quality assurance, regulation and standardization, policy development and 
reform, and resource mobilization. Activities of this component will include a review of major 
technical curative and preventive approaches based on studies, action research and pilot tests   
aiming at health sector reforms that focus on maternal and child health, health services for the 
poor, and sustainable delivery of PHC services in a decentralized setting. A focal point of 
support will be the promotion of public private partnership approaches related to community-
based health services planning and delivery, health financing and insurance, and health sector 
infrastructure12. The creation of a national partnership forum will facilitate the empowerment of 
professional associations, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and private service providers 
through selected human resource development activities. The DHS2 resources will also be used 
to finance the development of generic information, education, and training materials, and the 
development  of  a  competency-based  clinical  training  in  newly  created  provincial  teaching 
hospitals. In-country and overseas fellowships and comparative studies based on training needs 
assessments will help strengthen the capacity to analyze and respond to decentralization needs 
of the sector and to design and implement health sector reforms that will give priority to the 
reform  of  existing  health  centers,  which  particularly  cater  to  the  poor  segments  of  the 
population. Activities will include the development of a physical infrastructure for knowledge-
based and user-friendly management information systems. Under this component, the DHS2 
will help BKKBN cover the contraceptive needs of the poor during the transition period of 
decentralizing its services and until a sustainable financing mechanism has been developed for 
the procurement of contraceptives. 
 
C.  Special Features 
26.  The  DHS2  has  been  designed  to  support  decentralized  service  delivery,  like  its 
predecessor, DHS1. DHS2 has established full ownership by regional governments, through 
their detailed subproject proposals and their substantial budget contributions. The DHS2 will 
allow the national Government to specifically address shortcomings of service provision in 
individual regions by demanding compliance with obligatory functions and minimum service 
standards when approving annual plans of district/cities for funding by the DHS2. Due to the 
number  of  second-tier  governments  involved,  provincial  project  managers  will  consolidate 
annual plans before submission for approval by the Government and ADB. Individual district 
and city plans, including related comments from district and city health committees, will be 
submitted for information to the Government and to ADB. 
 
27.  Local leaders and health professionals will be supported to develop the capability to 
adequately  identify  specific  health  needs  of  poor  and  vulnerable  groups  and  implement 
appropriate programs by applying a participatory approach that involves the beneficiaries. This 
implies  a  priority  for  PHC  services  and  diseases  particularly  affecting  the  poor—such  as 
malaria, tuberculosis, acute respiratory infection, diarrhea, and malnutrition. PHC facilities most 
used by the poor will be strengthened, in particular health posts for village midwives, subhealth 
centers, and health centers. Reform of health centers has been identified as a priority activity of

29.  The DHS2 advocates spending of 5% of the regional annual budget for the health sector 
by the end of the DHS2 and will promote an integrated approach to health financing, cross-
sectoral coordination, public-private partnerships, monitoring of health service performance and 
of  health  status  indicators,  dissemination  of  information,  and  increased  transparency  and 
accountability. The DHS2 is funding the implementation and dissemination of successful pilot 
experiments related to health sector reforms and the local adaptation of national guidelines. For 
example, the DHS2 will support Bangka Belitung and Gorontalo provinces to develop and 
implement a social health insurance system.  
 
30.  Particularly in urban areas, individuals, companies, or NGOs provide private health 
services  that  try  to  directly  respond  to  demand.  Partnerships  between  public  and  private 
providers can improve the availability of health services for all, the quality of health services, 
and the increased efficiency in the allocation of resources. Such partnerships can improve the 
effectiveness of service delivery while mobilizing additional resources from those who can afford 
to pay, thus allowing an increase of public subsidies for the poor. The DHS2 will support the 
development of public-private partnerships in health care delivery and financing, which will need 
to materialize in annual health plans of regional governments.

F.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Project Management 
33.  MOH will be the Executing Agency for the DHS2. BKKBN will be the Implementing 
Agency for family planning and family welfare activities. The MOH secretary general will be the 
DHS2's director. The senior advisor to MOH dealing with decentralization will be the deputy 
director of MOH and will also act as the project manager of MOH. The principal secretary of 
BKKBN will be deputy director of BKKBN. Both deputy directors will provide policy guidance and 
ensure coordination with other projects supporting decentralization in each of their respective 
areas. The director of program and policy at BKKBN will be the deputy project manager of 
BKKBN. A national steering committee consisting, among others, of senior representatives from 
MOH, BKKBN, Ministry of Finance, National Development Planning Agency, Ministry of Home 
Affairs, and State Ministry of Empowerment of Women will provide advice to the DHS2's director 
on general policy and intersectoral coordination. A national technical team of ministry experts 
will advise the deputy directors. A diagram of the project organization is in Appendix 5. 
 
34.  The head of the provincial health services will be the provincial project manager (PPM).  
The PPM will be assisted by the provincial PIU, composed of a full-time executive secretary, 
finance officer, procurement officer, and monitoring and evaluation officer, who will coordinate 
project  implementation  in  the  province  and  provide  technical  support  to  their  participating 
districts. The PPM will report to the provincial governor or the head of the provincial BAPPEDA. 
A provincial health council with a wide representation of government services, professional 
associations, and civil society will be established to advise the regional project directors and 
ensure  transparency  of  decision-making.  A  provincial  technical  review  team,  including 
representatives from MOH and BKKBN, the private health sector, academics and professional 
organizations, and technical experts on an individual basis will assist the provincial PIU.  The 
provincial  PIU  will  support  and  coordinate  district  and  city  implementation  units  (DIU).  A 
provincial sub-PIU for BKKBN activities may be established as needed. 
 
35.  At the district and city level, a full-time district executive secretary will be responsible for 
implementing the project activities, under the guidance of the chief of the district and city health 
services who will be the district and city project manager (DPM). The DPM will report to the 
chief executive of the district and city. In each district and city, the chief executive of the district 
or city will establish a district health committee (DHC) to advise the DPM and monitor the 
implementation of DHS2 activities in accordance with the district’s annual plan of action. The 
DHC  will  include  representatives  of  the  district  health  and  family  planning  services,  local 
parliament, private health sector, community leaders, women’s organizations, NGOs, and other 
representatives of civil society.

update the district and city proposal for assistance under DHS2 and transmit the district and city 
annual plan for the following year to the PPM, including the minutes of the DHC and the DPM's 
response to the recommendations of DHS. At the provincial level, the district proposals will be 
reviewed  by  the  provincial  health  council  and  the  provincial  technical  review  team  and 
consolidated on a province-wide basis.  By July 1 of each year, the PPM will transmit the 
consolidated provincial proposal to the national project manager and deputy project directors, 
including a summary of the issues discussed by the provincial technical review team and the

provincial proposals (as they may be amended) and submit them to ADB by 1 August of each

year for approval. Flexibility will be provided to adapt project activities to newly identified needs

54.  Project Benefits and Beneficiaries. The DHS2 will improve health services in districts 
and cities in the 8 selected project provinces. The outcome will be a better health status of the 
concerned population at large and of poor and vulnerable groups in particular. DHS2 activities 
give  priority  to  common  health  problems  of  poor  and  vulnerable  groups,  such  as  child 
malnutrition, child and infant mortality, and maternal mortality. About 2 million women and 2 
million men will benefit from the DHS2, with 9%–32% of them below the poverty line. Because 
of the priority given to mother and child health care, women will benefit disproportionately from 
the DHS2. An estimated 180,000 infant girls will benefit from the DHS2 as part of 1.51 million 
under-five girls (315,000 of them considered to be poor).  
 
55.  Social and Poverty Analysis. In general, health services and facilities at village health 
posts, mobile health centers, village midwives, health centers cater to the poor. Poor people 
also use traditional healers and private health services providers because access to quality 
health services is often inadequate. In remote rural areas, health service facilities are often 
beyond the reach of the poor due to transport and high opportunity costs, or health services are 
often of low quality because of the difficulty to retain qualified health personnel in remote areas. 
The poor often cannot afford private health services except from NGOs, and the relatively low 
quality and ineffectiveness of the public health sector particularly affect their health status. 
Social and poverty issues are analyzed in detail in appendixes 10 and 11. 
 
56.  Ill health is the single most common trigger for the deterioration of the quality of life of 
poor and vulnerable groups. Illness reduces household savings, lowers learning ability, reduces

15
productivity, and leads to a diminished quality of life, thereby creating or perpetuating poverty. 
Compared with the general population, the poor and vulnerable groups are exposed to greater 
personal and environmental risks, are less well nourished, have less access to information, and 
are less able to access health care.  
 
57.  Vulnerable  groups  include  indigenous  peoples.  The  executing  and  implementing 
agencies will ensure that project activities have a positive impact on indigenous peoples. To 
ensure that indigenous peoples benefit from the DHS2, the following measures have been 
developed: (i) district health plans include an assessment of the needs of indigenous peoples; 
(ii) constraints on indigenous peoples’ participation in and/or benefiting from project activities will 
be addressed; (iii) community participation in the implementation of project activities will include 
indigenous peoples where relevant; and (iv) monitoring mechanism include the impact of the 
DHS2 on indigenous peoples. If civil works require resettlement, a resettlement plan will be 
prepared, in accordance with the resettlement framework (supplementary appendix B). 
 
58.  Access to health care is a top priority for women and their families, as women tend to be 
responsible for the care of the young, the sick, and the elderly. Thus, women’s access to health 
care extends beyond the welfare of the individual to that of the family as a whole. Women in 
rural areas will benefit from several project activities, in particular the upgrading of PHC and 
family planning services, strengthening of safe motherhood activities, improvement of training 
institutions  for  nurses  and  midwives,  and  development  of  disease  prevention  programs. 
Women's groups will help women learn about health issues and support each other in case of 
disease. Gender sensitive planning and budgeting will be promoted at the district level, sex-
disaggregated data on the health status of the population will be collected, and participation of 
women in managerial training will be supported. The DHS2 will promote increased numbers of 
female health staff by encouraging enrollment of women in staff development and training 
activities sponsored by the DHS2 and setting the target of a 50% participation rate. Other 
specific measures addressing gender issues are presented in the gender action plan prepared 
for the DHS2 (supplementary appendix C). 
 
59.  Environment. The DHS2 will rehabilitate and upgrade health facilities in the project 
area, such as hospitals, health centers, subhealth centers, and village health posts. An initial 
environmental assessment for project activities has been completed during project preparation. 
The necessary measures will be taken to minimize environmental impacts. Hospital waste 
management will become part of the capacity-building program. A summary is attached in 
Appendix 12. All civil works will be undertaken considering minimal damage to the environment. 
 
60.  Economic  and  Financial  Analysis.  While  the  DHS2  is  expected  to  yield  several 
benefits, the economic internal rate of return was calculated using a conservative estimate of 
the benefits of improved health of the population in the project provinces through improved use 
and  quality  of  health  services  at  the  district  level.    These  conservative  estimates  yield  a 
composite economic internal rate of return of 37%, with rates ranging from 21.5% in East Nusa 
Tenggara to 50.2% in South Sumatra. A detailed economic and financial analysis is in Appendix 
13. 
 
61.  The DHS2 is primarily expected to reduce the burden of disease, measured by the 
reduction in disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) lost due to death and disability.  Project 
benefits have been estimated in terms of reduction of the gap in DALY between the project 
provinces  and  developed  countries,  multiplied  by  the  2002  per  capita  provincial  minimum

16  
wages.  Data derived from the 1993 World Development Report14 indicates that the gap in 
DALY between non-Indian and Chinese Asian countries and established market economies was 
about 143 per 1000 population.  The gap in DALY is estimated by disaggregating the major 
disease categories, using relatively recent (1995) burden of disease data on previous health 
projects. The value of DALY saved in each province is the monetary value of the minimum wage 
levels in the province.15  For DHS2, the maximum benefit effect assumes a reduction of the gap 
by 7.4 DALYs per 1000 population. 
 
62.  The  total  financial  cost  of  the  DHS2,  inclusive  of  taxes,  duties,  contingencies,  and 
interest charges, is $143 million for a period of 6 years.  The DHS2 will provide funds to districts 
and  provinces  to  support  development  spending  to  achieve  increased  health  outcomes. 
Financial rates of return are not calculated since cost recovery is not a factor in the project 
design. Hence, fiscal impact analysis was done to evaluate the impact of the Project on the 
Government budget.  There is a wide variation both within and across provinces in health 
spending.  In most districts, the levels of health spending are about 1–2% of the local district 
budget expenditures. 
 
63.  Based on project disbursements, projections were made to assess the annual district 
health expenditure as a result of the incremental project investment so that the respective 
government is presented with clear funding commitment.  With the DHS2, total district health 
expenditure will average about 2% of local expenditures during the project period. This is 
considered to have minimal impact on local budgetary resources.  To make a substantial impact 
on key health indicators, however, a substantial increase in health spending will be required.  To 
avoid a sharp drop in spending by 2011, government health spending would have to increase 
during project implementation in order to sustain and deepen project benefits.  Although the 
costs of health system reforms are one-time costs, local government commitment will have to 
be obtained to ensure sustainability of the health reforms and to maintain the improved public 
health facilities.  Increased levels of health spending at the district and city level could be 
achieved  through  cross-subsidies  between  better-off  and  poor  areas,  increased  budgetary 
transfers  from  central  Government,  and  other  resource  mobilization  mechanisms  (e.g., 
community mobilization and public-private-partnerships). 
 
64.  Risks and Assumptions. With the participation of 98 regional governments and new 
decentralized  planning  and  budgeting  mechanisms  set  up  at  subnational  levels,  project 
administration will be challenging.  Leadership at the national level may not be strong enough to 
provide necessary regulatory guidance and technical support. DHS2 funds will therefore be 
used to contract qualified management staff to compensate for shortcomings in the provision of 
qualified staff at all levels of government. The DHS2 will also make the best possible use of 
information and communication technology for supervision, monitoring, and distance support. 
  
65.  Increased  local  autonomy  over  resource  allocation  may  follow  short-term  political 
incentives, for example high profile support for hospital services. Project activities will facilitate 
policy dialogue with regional governments to advocate investment in the health sector aiming at 
an allocation of least 5% of the regional annual budget for health by the end of the DHS2. Each 
region will establish a midterm target that will become part of the PPMS. All capacity-building 
and  advocacy  activities  of  the  DHS2  strongly  emphasize  more  cost-efficient  allocations  of 
resources and the needs of the poor.

66.  Issues of good governance will be addressed by (i) improved supervision by the central

V.  ASSURANCES 
A.  Specific Assurances 
68.  In addition to the standard assurances, the Government and MOH and BKKBN have 
given the following assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents: 
 
69.  Annual Plans. By 1 June of each year, beginning June 2004, the DHC, DPM, and DIU 
will review and update the district proposal for assistance under the DHS2 and transmit the plan 
to the PPM, including the minutes of the DHC and DPM's response to recommendations of the 
DHC. At the provincial level, district proposals will be reviewed by the provincial technical review 
team and consolidated on a province-wide basis. By 1 July of each year, the provincial technical 
review team will transmit the consolidated provincial proposal to the national project manager 
including a summary of the issues discussed by the provincial technical review team and the 
solutions  proposed.    After  review  of  the  consolidated  provincial  proposals  by  the  national 
technical team, the national project manager will endorse the provincial proposals (as they may 
be amended) and submit them to ADB by 1 August of each year for approval. 
 
70.  Counterpart Funds. The Borrower will ensure that all necessary counterpart funds for 
project implementation at the national level are provided in a timely manner and take all other 
measures necessary or appropriate for prompt disbursement of national funds to the project 
provinces and project districts during each year of implementation. The Borrower will ensure 
that participating districts, cities, and provinces are aware of the need to provide counterpart 
funding for project activities and that they are informed that a failure to produce the required 
counterpart funding for more than 1 year will result in that participating province, district or city 
being ineligible for further participation in the DHS2, unless otherwise agreed by ADB.  
 
71.  Except as ADB may otherwise agree, the Borrower will ensure that, throughout the 
period of project implementation, the proceeds of the loan, and the corresponding amount of 
necessary counterpart funds, will be disbursed to project provinces and project districts, by 
budgetary transfers of funds earmarked for such purpose. 
 
72.  The Government has given the following assurances in relation to the application of the 
MOF  decree  35/2003  on  Planning,  Implementation/Administration,  and  Monitoring  of 
Government Subsidiary Offshore Loans to Regions. 
 
(i)  All  funds  distributed  under  the  DHS2  to  the  participating  districts,  cities,  and 
provinces  will  be  for  noncost  recovery  and  nonrevenue  generating projects,  and 
therefore, the funds so distributed are grants to the participating regions.

and the counterpart contribution. 
  
(iii)  The signing of the "ongranting" agreement, regardless of the actual date of signing,

73.  Auditing.  The  Borrower  will  ensure  that  any  independent  auditors  financed  from 
proceeds of the loan will be selected and engaged in accordance with competitive selection 
procedures acceptable to ADB. 
 
74.  The Borrower will ensure that all project provinces, and all project districts and cities, 
MOH and BKKBN maintain a separate accounting system for DHS2 expenditures in accordance 
with sound accounting principles.  All project accounts, including financial statement, statements 
of expenditures, and account records will be audited annually as part of the regular audit 
accounts  and  financial  statements.    District  and  city  accounts  will  be  audited  by  auditors 
acceptable to ADB, and consolidated at the provincial level.  The consolidated eight provincial 
and two national audit reports (one for MOH and one for BKKBN) will be submitted in English 
language to ADB within 9 months after the end of the Government's fiscal year. 
 
75.  Reporting. The Government will coordinate and cooperate with ADB in reviewing the 
DHS2 and in this connection, will submit to ADB documents and reports that may be required. 
Within 3 months after the loan closing date, the provinces and the Government will submit a 
project completion report to ADB, in such form and detail as ADB may request. 
   
76.  The CPCU will submit to ADB, within 30 days after the end of each calendar quarter, 
consolidated progress reports on the DHS2 in a form agreed upon by the Government and ADB.

accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Bank Operations, 
and the following:

quantitative data on the poor and vulnerable groups living in the referenced 
geographic  area  (including  internally  displaced  persons  and  indigenous 
peoples), disaggregated by gender. 
 
(ii)  The health information management system and performance monitoring system 
for the DHS2 will provide gender disaggregated data and information.

ensure that women constitute at least 50% of all persons trained pursuant to the DHS2's 
activities and that this percentage is applied to each category of training program. The Borrower 
will  ensure  that  the  gender  action  plan,  as  agreed  upon  by  the  Borrower  and  ADB,  is 
implemented in all DHS2 activities.

loan effective date, all land acquisition and resettlement activities will have been completed in 
accordance  with  the  resettlement  framework  agreed  upon  by  the  Borrower  and  ADB;  the 
Borrower's laws, regulations, and procedures; and ADB's requirements as defined in ADB's 
Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and the Handbook on Resettlement.  No civil works will 
commence in any geographic area prior to completion of resettlement and income restoration 
activities in that geographic area.

promote  full  participation  of  indigenous  peoples  in  project  activities,  including  developing

actions  taken  as  a  result  of  the  DHS2  are  in  accordance  with  the  ADB's  Environmental

6.  Tuberculosis is a priority health problem in Indonesia causing a disease burden nearly 
double that of neighboring countries. Nearly 600,000 new cases occur each year, amounting to 
280 new cases per 100,000 people, including 126 smear positive pulmonary cases per 100,000. 
Estimates show that only 20% of pulmonary tuberculosis is detected. Of those detected with 
tuberculosis, an estimated 87% were successfully treated.6 
 
7.   More than 50% of the population lives in malaria-free areas where transmission does not 
exist or occurs only sporadically. Malaria is a health problem in forest areas of the outer islands, 
particularly in the eastern provinces, where 50% of the cases are plasmodium falciparum. More 
than 1.5 million clinical cases are reported outside Java annually. Malaria control activities are 
integrated  with  the  general  health  services.  Overall  responsibility  for  implementing  malaria 
control activities lies with district governments. Passive case detection, clinical diagnosis and 
treatment, active case detection and laboratory diagnosis are limited to the Java-Bali area. 
Malaria cases are treated at health centers, private practices, and malaria treatment posts of 
volunteers in the rural areas. The spread of drug resistance, a lack of resources, and a lack of 
intersector collaboration and trained professional staff are some of the major issues. 
 
8.   The population at risk of malaria is around 100 million (46.2% of the population). Based 
on the malaria incidence, Indonesia is divided into two regions, Java and Bali, with 70% of the 
total Indonesian population, where malaria is hypoendemic, and the other sparsely populated 
islands where malaria is at much higher levels. More than 3.3 million clinical cases of malaria 
were reported in 1998 by government health centers and hospitals. As only 20% of sick people 
go to the government facilities, an estimated 15 million malaria cases probably occur annually. 
The loss of individual income from malaria is estimated at $56.5 million per year, not including 
the loss from tourism and foregone business investment in malaria endemic areas.

9.  An expanded program on immunization had been implemented since 1978, and the 
coverage increased rapidly. Indonesia achieved the universal child immunization level by 1990 
at the national level and in all provinces in 1994, but only around 65% districts achieved that

area approach). 
 
10.  The  epidemiological  transition  places  a  double  burden  on  the  health  system:  while 
communicable diseases remain major public health issues, non-communicable diseases are 
increasing  (e.g.,  over  40%  of  outpatient  cases  at  the  health  center  level  are  there  for 
hypertension, asthma, etc). Smoking is a major contributor to these diseases but there is little 
political  will  to  develop  strategies  to  counter  the  trend.  Degenerative  and  non-contagious 
diseases also show a rising trend.  The results of the National Household Health Survey of 1995 
show that 83 persons per 1,000 people suffer from hypertension, and 2 to 3 persons per 1,000 
people from ischemic heart disease and stroke.  Emotional disturbances among people aged 5–
14 years old and above 15 are 104 and 140 per 1,000 people, respectively.  Blindness is rising 
significantly, from 1.0% in 1982 to 1.47% in 1995.  Mortality due to traffic accidents increased 
from 3.2 per 100,000 people in 1994 to 4.1 per 100,000 people in 1997. 
 
11.  The prevalence of moderate and severe protein energy malnutrition among children 
under 5 years had dropped from 18.9% in 1978 to 14.6% in 1995.  The total prevalence of 
protein energy malnutrition decreased from 48.2% in 1978 to 35.0% in 1995.  So did the other 
nutritional problems decline, such as blindness due to vitamin A deficiency, iron deficiency 
anemia,  and  iodine  deficiency.  A  1992  survey  concluded  that  blindness  due  to  vitamin  A 
deficiency was no longer a community health problem. The National Socioeconomic Survey 
disclosed that the prevalence of pregnant women suffering from iron deficiency had decreased 
from 63.5% in 1992 to 50.5% in 1995.  Among the preschool-age group, iron deficiency went 
down from 55.5% to 40.5%.  Iodine deficiency disease declined because 80% of households 
used iodized salt.  
 
12.  The issue of malnutrition, however, needs to be further discussed in the light of the 
aftermath of 1997 economic crisis and the start of the decentralization process in 2001, as its 
transition period had upset distribution programs. Groups at highest risk are children 5–12 
months. Maternal malnutrition and anemia are concerns for over 50% children 5–14 and women 
of  reproductive  age.  The  National  Socio-economic  Survey  (Susenas)  2001  showed  that 
prevalence of stunting under-five is 34.3%, wasting under-five is 16.6%, under-five children with 
anemia is 47.8%. These programs will need to be strengthened at the local levels.

2.  The  project  objective  is  to  improve  the  health  and  family  planning  status  of  the

Kalimantan,  East  Nusa  Tenggara,  Gorontalo,  South  Kalimantan,  South  Sulawesi,  South

vulnerable;  (iii)  improving  of  the  efficiency,  effectiveness  and  quality  of  health  and  family

of health professionals; and (v) improved participation of the community, including the poor and 
vulnerable groups, in voicing their needs and priorities to the relevant health professionals.

centers have in turn, several auxiliary health centers at the village level. Contracted village 
midwives supervised by the local health center are working at the community level in village-
owned  birthing  posts  (Pos  Persalinan  Desa—POLINDES).  Health  referrals  are  handled  at 
district hospitals, which have 50–200 beds. Further referrals are handled at provincial or central-
level general hospitals and national specialty hospital centers.

to determine the extent of processing needed. Where groundwater is not suitable for use, clean 
water needs to be transported if municipal water mains are not available. Clean and adequate 
water supplies for the centers and housing need to be carefully ensured. 
 
3.  Ecological Resources 
15.  The vegetation at most health facilities is well maintained, except in Kuin Raya, where 
tides and dense population make vegetation care difficult. The proposed hospital location in 
Batulicin has no tall trees, and no flora that need to be conserved.  
 
16.  No endangered species, wildlife, and wildlife habitat were identified on the premises or 
surrounding area of the DHS2 health facilities. The wildlife identified were limited to common 
wild birds; mammals (cats, rats, and small rodents); and insects (ants, cockroaches, flies, and 
bees). 
 
4.  Human and Economic Development 
17.  Batu  Licin,  the  capital  of  Tanah  Bumbu  district,  has  not  yet  adequate  community 
sanitation facilities. The new hospital will have to develop its own wastewater treatment system 
area. Most hospitals need a diesel generator as electricity outages occur, due to the limited 
resources  of  the  state  electricity  company.  Many  health  centers  are  not  connected  to  an 
electricity source. Vaccines are stored in kerosene-powered cold storage.  
 
D.  Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures  
18.  Present  environmental  laws  and  Ministry  of  Health  and  Ministry  of  Environment 
regulations and guidelines provide sufficient safeguards for the environmentally safe operation 
of health facilities. Enforcement of the regulations needs improvement. 
 
19.  Medical waste from hospitals and health centers should be burned in incinerators or 
other  high  temperature  furnaces.  This  needs  the  serious  attention  of  the  health  facility 
management because careful handling is essential.

20.  Hospital and health center wastewater should go a wastewater treatment plant before 
draining to the open environment or public sewerage, or absorption into the ground. The size of 
the plant needs to be carefully calculated by the architect or contractor, taking into consideration 
the actual load posed by patients, relatives, visitors, and health personnel. A plant for a health 
center may be a simple septic tank, as long as local ground conditions are also taken into 
consideration in the design of the effluent absorption area.  
 
21.  Construction  Phase.  Adverse  environmental  impacts  associated  with  the 
implementation of civil works will be minimal, short-term, and mitigated by appropriate design 
and project management of facilities construction and operation. Trees near health facilities will 
be replanted, and other vegetation restored.  
 
22.  Indoor Quality And Energy Efficiency. To ensure good indoor quality, the building 
design should incorporate a natural lighting and tropical climate ventilation system as much as 
possible.  Whenever  natural  ventilation  is  inadequate,  fans  and  air  conditioning  may  be 
employed. In-patient facilities need to be designed to avoid the spread of contamination and 
infections  among  patients.  Energy  efficiency  can  be  achieved  if  all  users  economize  on 
electricity usage. This entails adequate socialization and enforcement by the management for 
all concerned (staff, patients, visitors, and other personnel). Other energy saving measures 
include the use of solar water heating and automatic switching for open public area lighting.  
 
23.  Green Gas Emissions. Incinerators need to be carefully chosen to ensure that the 
recommended working temperature can always be achieved. Incinerators and back-up diesel 
generators need to be kept in good condition to ensure complete combustion that helps keep 
the environment clean. Their location and exhaust stacks need to be carefully designed to 
minimize  noise  and  smoke  pollution.  The  use  of  renewable  energy  sources  is  preferable 
whenever technically and economically feasible. Solar energy is still prohibitively expensive as 
the equipment is not readily available and there are no trained personnel able to maintain it. 
 
24.  Institutional  Requirements  and  Environmental  Monitoring  Program.  Existing 
environmental laws and regulations form the basis for collection and disposal of medical waste. 
Environment monitoring and evaluation activities of the health facility and its surrounding area 
will follow the existing standards. Engineers will incorporate environmental impact mitigation 
measures into the technical design of DHS2 facilities. Construction and operation phases will 
include  mitigation  measures  as  needed.  Engineers  will  be  responsible  for  developing  an 
environmental  management  plan  for  each  subproject,  which  will  summarize  proposed 
environmental mitigation activities, including time-bound action plan, containing performance 
evaluation of specific environmental, health, and safety activities as reflected in the results of 
periodic and quantitative sampling and measuring programs. The provincial and district health 
office, the local environmental impact management agency (BAPEDAL) and the Ministry of 
Health will provide technical guidance in preparing the plan following national guidelines.  
 
25.  A committee to monitor the quality of civil works and environment will be set up at each 
district and city in order to monitor and evaluate compliance according to the EMP milestones. 
The committee will be composed of a DHS2 district coordinator, the local BAPEDAL, and the 
district health office. Periodic site supervision visits will also be conducted. The committee’s 
report will be a part of the project progress report.

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
A.  Economic Analysis 
 
1.  Economic Rationale 
 
1.  The Second Decentralized Health Services Project (DHS2) focuses on improving the 
role  of  government  in  the  sector  in  a  decentralized  context.  Decentralization  offers  new 
opportunities to strengthen health and family planning services in the regions through locally 
adapted  reforms  giving  health  services  providers  more  appropriate  incentives,  skills, 
supervision, material support, and discretionary authority needed to offer high quality services, 
and providing clients with information, financial means, and bargaining power required to elicit 
appropriate responses. Investments are needed to help the regions and the central Government 
plan, implement, manage, monitor, and evaluate a range of programs and activities. DHS2 will 
strengthen capacity at district, provincial, and national levels for the delivery of health services.  
It will include planning and management to ensure universal access to good quality health and 
family planning services, and to improve quality, cost efficiency, and sustainability of health and 
family planning services in the DHS2 area. The initial advocacy, training, and technical support 
will build up commitment and capacity of regional governments. The leading role of the public 
health sector in decentralization will require strong support and participation from a variety of 
stakeholders. The DHS2 will also address the increasingly important role of the private health 
sector, the professional associations, and the community in the organization and governance of 
the health system. The primary focus of the DHS2 will be poor and vulnerable groups, and the 
underserved.  DHS2’s support to primary health care (PHC) will play a key role in the decrease 
of maternal and infant mortality, and general morbidity. 
 
2.  Economic Benefits 
2.  The DHS2 is expected to yield several benefits.  These include improved health status in 
the  provinces  and  districts  through  increased  spending  for  health,  better  prioritization  and 
targeting of health services, improved resource mobilization, enhanced service quality, and 
better access for vulnerable groups. Regional authorities informed of local concerns will devise 
more cost-efficient health service delivery systems. The DHS2 increases the economic benefits 
of  decentralization  at  the  provincial  and  district  levels  through  capacity  building,  physical 
investment, and reforms. While there may be savings in the health reforms, such savings will be 
directed to increasing subsidies to the poor. Health promotion activities will also be targeted 
towards women and the poor to increase health status.  
 
3.   The DHS2 is expected to contribute to the reduction in the burden disease measured by 
the reduction in disability adjusted life years (DALYs) lost due to death and disability.  Project 
benefits have been estimated in terms of reduction of the gap in DALY between the project 
provinces and developed countries, multiplied by the 2002 per capita regional minimum wages.  
Data  derived  from  the  1993  World  Development  Report1  indicates  that  the  gap  in  DALY 
between non-Indian and Chinese Asian countries and established market economies was about 
143 per 1000 population.  The gap in DALY is estimated by disaggregating the major disease 
categories, using relatively recent burden of disease data from previous health projects. The 
value of a DALY saved in each province is the monetary value of the minimum wage levels in

B.  Financial Sustainability and Fiscal Impact  
 
7.  The DHS2 comprises investment and capacity building components.  Financial rate of 
return is not calculated since investment is on PHC, considered as core poverty reduction 
activities,4 and user charges will not be applied in the investment project. Hence, cost recovery 
is not al factor in the project design. The financial analysis focuses on the fiscal impact of the 
DHS2 on regional government budgets. Sustainability analysis of funding for project activities 
beyond the closing date is also presented. 
 
8.  Government health expenditure is low by international standards. Chronically low funding 
of public health services has affected service quality and effectiveness, which in turn have had

an impact on the use of public health services and the health status of the population.   In 
selected provinces in the country, district allocations for health are only about two to eight 
percent of the local health budget.5 Hence, it is essential that health service delivery achieve (i) 
greater  cost-efficiency  in  resource  allocation,  and  (ii)  increased  resource  mobilization. 
Investments in PHC and family planning services are a cost-effective means of providing quality 
PHC  services.  Rationalizing  personnel,  increasing  public-private  partnership,  and  resource 
mobilization are the proposed reform options for the districts and provinces. Better public-private 
partnership also will get the private sector more involved in health care financing, managed care 
and other reforms. 
 
9.  About 30% of the DHS2 will be financed by the national Government and the loan 
proceeds will be forwarded to the regions as a grant (ongranting mechanisms). From a total cost 
of $143 million, the Government will finance about $43.0 million. The Government’s annual 
share in project costs will average around $7.2 million during the project period. The recurrent 
costs to be borne by the Government during the DHS2 are estimated to be about $1.6 million 
per year.  DHS2 is designed to minimize recurrent cost implications for the Government and the 
community. The improvement of the quality and management support systems in DHS2 is 
intended  to  improve  the  internal  efficiency  of  the  health  system.  The  development  of  a 
appropriate and improved system will result in an efficient use of resources and an effective 
delivery of health services. The costs associated with system development are one time costs to 
support  reforms,  and  therefore  the  incremental  costs  from  the  DHS2  are  negligible  and 
sustainable. 
 
10.  Based on project disbursements, projections were made to assess the annual district 
health expenditure as a result of the incremental project investment so that the Government is 
presented with a clear funding commitment. Currently, in the eight provinces supported by the 
project, there is a wide variation both within and across provinces in health spending.  In most of 
the project districts, the levels of health spending are about 1 to 2% of the local district budget 
expenditures.  DHS2  will  provide  funds  to  districts  and  provinces  to  support  development 
spending to achieve increased health outcomes. With the DHS2, total district health expenditure 
will comprise an average of about 2% of local expenditures during the project period. This is 
considered to have minimal impact on local budgetary resources.  In order to make substantial 
impact on key health indicators, however, substantial increase in health spending would be 
required. To avoid a sharp drop in spending by 2011, public health spending would have to 
increase during project implementation in order to sustain and deepen project benefits. Local 
government commitment will have to be obtained to ensure sustainability of the health reforms 
and to maintain the improved public health facilities.  Increased levels of health spending at the 
district level could be achieved through cross-subsidies between better-off and poor areas, and 
other  resource  mobilization  mechanisms  (community  mobilization  and  public-private-
partnerships).
